posts.cooked: We will thoroughly calibrate our cams but first want to know any helpful tricks or tips to improve accuracy. We’re also curious about the current settings (resolution, decimation, etc.) used by others. By how many turns do you think cam users usually twist them for focusing?

posts.name: SLAB-Mr.Thomas
posts.cooked:
I don’t have a ThriftyCam, so I don’t understand your question. To focus a camera generally, point it at an object at the desired distance and adjust the lens position until the object appears sharpest, likely by slightly twisting the lens in its screw mount relative to the camera. Objects like Text and Lines or an AprilTag with its ID visible can serve as good subjects. Using a Siemens Star or another pattern may help measure sharpness. There’s also software like Limelight, though the manual method involving a quick eyeball adjustment is simpler and more practical.

The code snippet demonstrates using the Laplacian operator to highlight edges via second derivatives, then computes mean and standard deviation. While effective, the manual method remains preferable due to its simplicity and accuracy.

posts.name: John Fogarty
posts.cooked:
What calibration results did you get? We used a purchased Charuco board to achieve a reprojection error of approximately 0.5 pixels. Our strategy involved positioning the board 2 feet away and capturing 50+ images from various angles to cover the calibration window fully.  

For focus, twisting the lens until the target appears sharp or tracked at the desired distance is essentially all we do.  

Settings vary depending on the coprocessor; however, it’s important to use compatible decimate/resolution settings similar to those described below once you obtain your new OrangePi. While our current approach is specific, more general information will become available shortly.

Thank you for the reply. Changing the focus on the thrifty cams requires manually adjusting the lens distance to the sensor. I was wondering about the optimal setup—specifically, what focal lengths work best for both faraway tags (like 2 meters) and closer ones. After making this adjustment, do you think applying a strip of tape or adhesive along the lens side would help keep it stable?

We haven't yet calibrated the cameras and will provide you with the information tomorrow after we complete the calibration. Regarding your query, we would recommend either purchasing a Charuco board or printing one that uses the [PV] technology, as it provides specific features beneficial for our applications. Additionally, we would suggest using the [PV] calibration method due to its accuracy and efficiency. Lastly, concerning AprilTags' distances changing during the match, we had to adjust the sharpness settings to accommodate both far and close tags.

posts.name: John Fogarty
posts.cooked:
Sharpness setup for a distance within 4-6 feet worked well enough to also see tags that were much further away. Focus with such a small lens doesn't require that much of a headache.

I would not use a printed one. I would either buy one or use an iPad/tablet screen and measure the square size with calipers.

Looking for a reliable and affordable way to calibrate your cameras for 2025? I'm excited to share a new product: Charuco Calibration Targets, designed specifically for teams looking to achieve professional-quality camera calibration without breaking the bank. Flat and Durable: Made from 6mm aluminum composite, these targets stay flat, ensuring consistent and accurate calibration results. Cost-Effective: Comparable to professional-grade targets but at a fraction of the price.
The resolution you choose won't alter the charuco board.

posts.name: John Fogarty
posts.cooked: Calibration requires setting your camera to the optimal resolution for tracking, aiming for the highest framerate/latency balance. Regardless of the resolution chosen, the underlying hardware remains consistent.
Oh, I get it now! That makes sense. Thank you!

posts.name: SLAB-Mr.Thomas
posts.cooked:
There is some uncertainty about the precision of pose accuracy when using distant AprilTags, especially with larger standard deviations. However, if you're committed to extracting that final bit of information, here's a suggested approach:

While observing the 3D pose wireframe displayed on the AprilTag positioned at your desired maximum viewing distance, adjust the focus so the wireframe becomes visible and then disappears. Mark the midpoint between the most clockwise and counterclockwise positions where the wireframe is present. This spot represents the optimal location for accurate tag interpretation.

Closing in on the tags may result in slight blurriness, but the initial detection process inherently involves a blur function. Ensure that different tags are detectable and interpretable across all target distances.

If the camera isn't tightly secured in its mount, consider applying a small amount of hot glue for stability. However, due to limited oversight during testing, there's concern about potential damage to the robot or camera during transportation.
Okay, I'll try this tomorrow during Robotics.

posts.name: SLAB-Mr.Thomas
posts.cooked: Arguably back left is the outlier. I’d calibrate it 2 or 3 more times and see what I get.
